sub_topic: Finding the antiderivative of a function
message_1: Find the antiderivative of the function f(x) = 2x^3 - 4x^2 + 7x - 9.
message_2:
To find the antiderivative of the function f(x) = 2x^3 - 4x^2 + 7x - 9, we will integrate the function with respect to x. 

The antiderivative F(x) is given by:

F(x) = ∫(2x^3 - 4x^2 + 7x - 9) dx

We will integrate each term separately:

∫2x^3 dx = (2/4)x^4 = (1/2)x^4
∫-4x^2 dx = (-4/3)x^3
∫7x dx = (7/2)x^2
∫-9 dx = -9x

Now, we will add all the integrated terms together and include the constant of integration, C:

F(x) = (1/2)x^4 - (4/3)x^3 + (7/2)x^2 - 9x + C
